facts.text: Four persons appeal against sentences of death passed upon them for convictions for a double murder of brothers Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BosE J.-Four persons appeal against sentences of death passed upon them in companyvictions for a double murder, the victims being two brothers, Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted three others also but sentenced all seven, including the four appellants, to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted three others also but sentenced all, including the four appellants, to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court acquitted three of the seven but sustained the convictions of the four appellants and enhanced their sentences to death.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court acquitted three of the seven but sustained the companyvictions of the four appellants and enhanced their sentences in each case to death.

facts.text: All seven accused belong to the same village and belong to the same faction or party.

anchor.surface_text: All seven accused belong to the same village and belong to the same faction or party, as Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  calls it.

facts.text: Appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers.

anchor.surface_text: Of the seven, the appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers.

facts.text: Jarnail Singh who was acquitted is a son of Battan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Jarnail Singh who was acquitted is a son of Battan Singh.

facts.text: Appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh assaulted the two dead men Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are said to have assaulted the two dead men Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence.

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh were prosecuted and convicted and served short terms of imprisonment for the prior assault.

anchor.surface_text: They were prosecuted and companyvicted and served short terms of imprisonment.

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh believed that the two dead men used to furnish information against them to the police. This is the motive for the murders.

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are also said to be dacoits and it is said that they believed that the two dead men used to furnish information against them to the police. This is said to be the motive for the murders.

facts.text: On 16th June, 1951, about 2 p.m., Rattan Singh was taking some food out to a well a short distance from his house.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is as follows-On 16th June, 1951, Rattan Singh was taking some food out to a well a short distance from his house for himself and his son. This was about 2 p.m.

facts.text: Mst. Punnan PW 2 heard cries of alarm and on rushing out with her daughter Mst. Charni PW 11 saw all seven accused assaulting her husband Rattan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Just as he left the house, his wife Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  heard cries of alarm and on rushing out with her daughter Mst. Charni  P.W. 11  saw all seven accused assaulting her husband.

facts.text: Accused beat Rattan Singh up till he fell to the ground.

anchor.surface_text: They beat him up till he fell to the ground.

facts.text: Accused left Rattan Singh and rushed to his Haveli where Bawa Singh was lying on a cot.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as Rattan Singh fell down, they left him and rushed to his  Rattan Singhs  Haveli where the other brother Bawa Singh was lying on a company

facts.text: All seven belaboured Bawa Singh on the cot, dragged him out and beat him up some more.

anchor.surface_text: shouting that they would also make short work of him. All seven belaboured him on the company, then they dragged him out and beat him up some more.

facts.text: Accused returned to Rattan Singh and gave him some more blows, then ran away.

anchor.surface_text: After this they returned to where Rattan Singh was still lying on the ground and gave him some more blows. Then they ran away.

facts.text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after the assault. Rattan Singh survived a little longer but died not long after.

anchor.surface_text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after the assault. The other brother survived a little longer but he also died number long after.

facts.text: Weapons: appellants Dalip Singh and Sadhu Singh with barchhas, appellant Battan Singh and two acquitted with lathis, appellant Kundan Singh had a takwa (hatchet), accused Kehar Singh (acquitted) had a khunda.

anchor.surface_text: According to Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  the accused were armed as follows The appellants Dalip Singh and Sadhu Singh with barchhas the appellant Battan Singh and two of the accused who have been acquitted with lathis the appellant Kundan Singh had a takwa -a hatchet with along handle, and the accused Kehar Singh, who has been acquitted, had a khunda-a hefty stick with a curved iron end.

facts.text: Rattan Singh had nineteen injuries, two on head fatal (blunt), six grievous on non-vital parts.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence discloses that Rattan Singh had nineteen injuries on his person. Of these, only two, on the head, would have been fatal in themselves. The rest were on number-vital parts like the foot, ankle, leg, knee, thigh, buttock, forearm and wrist, but of these six were grievous.

facts.text: Appellant Dalip Singh arrested on 17th June, other three appellants on 18th June, each wearing blood-stained clothes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Dalip Singh was arrested on the 17th June and the other three on the 18th. Each was wearing blood-stained clothes.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted each of the seven accused under section 302 read with section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: But he was impressed with the evidence of the two eyewitnesses Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  and Mst. Charni W. 11  and believing them companyvicted each of the seven accused under section 302 read with section 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court sustained convictions of four appellants based on blood-stained clothes corroborating eyewitnesses.

anchor.surface_text: They found companyroboration in the case of the four appellants because of the blood-stained clothes and numbere in the case of the others. Accordingly, they companyvicted the four appellants and acquitted the others.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld convictions under section 302/149 for the four appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the companyviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these companyvictions.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside death sentences, restored life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

issues.text: Whether conviction under section 302 read with section 149 IPC can be sustained given the High Court's inconsistent findings that there were at least five participants but the three acquitted accused may or may not have participated, creating uncertainty about the minimum number required for section 149?

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, not do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149. But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object. It is true that in one place the learned Judges say that there were certainly not less than five present but in the very next breath they say that the three whom they acquit may or may not have taken part in the affair.

issues.text: Whether section 34 IPC can be applied in the alternative to sustain the convictions?

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing. In the circumstances, we find ourselves unable to allow the conviction to rest on the insecure foundations laid by the High Court.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of the two eyewitnesses (related women witnesses) requires corroboration as a rule of prudence?

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur.

issues.text: Whether the High Court properly exercised discretion in enhancing the sentence from transportation for life to death in a murder case under section 302/149 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.

holdings.text: The testimony of the two eyewitnesses does not require corroboration merely because they are women or closely related to the deceased; there is no such general rule of prudence.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's view; relationship often guarantees truth unless enmity shown; cites Rameshwar v. State of Rajasthan; each case on own facts, no general rule like for accomplices.

holdings.text: Section 149 IPC cannot be applied on an uncertain foundation where the court finds that three accused 'may or may not' have participated, as it requires certainty of at least five persons sharing the common object.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149. But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's inconsistent findings create uncertainty about minimum five; conviction cannot rest on vacillating conclusions, especially in murder with death sentences.

holdings.text: Section 34 IPC cannot be resorted to as the accused were not charged under it even in the alternative, and common intention under s.34 differs from common object under s.149.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar as not charged; substantive distinction between intention and object.

holdings.text: Convictions of the four appellants under section 302 read with section 149 IPC are upheld, as eyewitness testimony is credible, corroborated by FIR, blood-stained clothes, and weapons recovery, establishing all seven participated.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent review of evidence agrees with Sessions Judge; witnesses reliable, no enmity proven, consistent FIR names all seven, independent links via recoveries and blood; at least five (actually seven) for s.149 satisfied.

holdings.text: In murder cases, death sentence is ordinarily imposed unless trial judge records reasons for lesser penalty; appellate court interferes with enhancement only if discretion improperly exercised.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of trial judge discretion in sentencing; enhancement rare, requires strongest reasons; here, no individual fatal injury attribution, vicarious liability under s.149 justifies uniform life sentences.

holdings.text: The Sessions Judge properly exercised discretion in awarding transportation for life instead of death, as fatal injuries not attributable to any one accused; High Court enhancement without reasons is improper.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge. Whether we ourselves would have acted differently had we been the trial court is not the proper criterion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons inferable: multiple blunt injuries, no specific fatal actor identified, s.149 vicarious responsibility; appellate restraint applies.

precedents.cited_proposition: No general rule of prudence requires corroboration of testimony from close relatives of the deceased merely because of the relationship; such a view is a fallacy.

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions of four appellants under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC upheld; High Court acquittals of other three upheld; death sentences set aside and Sessions Judge's sentences of transportation for life restored as High Court improperly exercised discretion in enhancing sentence
